Feel free to take pictures, the guide will explain the different elements that make up the altars, and meaning behing the colors ,candles, and more . We will return to Mexico City in the early evening (around 18:00hrs) for overnight. Overnight in Mexico City.

Mexico City, Mexico: Local Market Visit & Day of the Dead Festivities in Mixquic Today we will have a morning visit to Jamaica market, famous for its ornamental flowers. In addition to the impressive variety of flowers you will also get to see altars and even stop for lunch if you’re feeling peckish (not included). You will then return to your accommodation around midday. Later on in the afternoon we will visit the town of Mixquic, famous for its vibrant and energetic Day of the Dead festivities. A big part of Day of the Dead is the light-hearted festivities that families organise in the local cemeteries to spend time with their deceased loved ones. The ceremony starts in the afternoon when families colourfully decorate the graves of their loved ones and continues late into the night with parties, music, dancing, and of course a good dose of tequila. Immerse yourself in the spirit as this is sure to be a unique experience! Overnight in Mexico City.

Mexico City, Mexico: Mexico City Free Day Today you are free to enjoy the magnificent capital of Mexico City at you own leisure. It's been an action-packed few days - maybe you want to rest! If not, there are countless things to do in Mexico City that you can organize at your own convenience. If enough of your group is interested, a uniquely Mexican outing to Xochimilco can be organized locally at an additional cost. You will cruse the canals of Xochimilco, enjoying cold beverages and snacks of your choosing (not included). Tonight, enjoy a goodbye dinner and drinks during a fun night out (not included). Embrace the festivities and atmosphere of the Day of the Dead during a lively last evening with your new travel friends, it will be a night to remember! After, if you feel up to it, go for a night out at some of the hippest spots Mexico City has to offer! Don't forget to try some mezcal, a unique beverage derived from the agave plant. When you're ready, head back to your accommodations. Overnight in Mexico City.

Mexico City, Mexico: Accommodation Check-Out Check out of your accommodation and say goodbye to your new friends over breakfast. Your unforgettable trip ends here. We wish you luck on your journey onward!

tourName: Espiritu Santo sea kayaking tour in Baja
generalInfo:
Boasting some of the world’s most beautiful beaches, Isla Espiritu Santo lies just off the southeast coast of Baja California. This adventurous trip includes days spent kayaking through the pristine waters of this UNESCO Biosphere Reserve where dramatic headlands plunge into the turquoise waters of the Sea of Cortez.  
 
Aside from its healthy populations of pelicans and dolphins, Isla Espiritu Santo remains uninhabited, which only adds to its allure. You’ll have the opportunity to go hiking through its colorful arroyos with their iconic cacti and snorkel amidst hundreds of tropical fish on the shallow reefs. Nights will be spent at spellbindingly beautiful beach camps where you’ll be treated to unparalleled stargazing in the skies above. 
 
A highlight of the trip is snorkeling with sea lions at Los Islotes, a series of volcanic islets where playful pups can be seen diving into the waters below. There is also the option to add on a day tour to go snorkeling with whale sharks off the coast of La Paz at the end of your trip.  
 
This kayaking trip is panga-supported and all of the heavier gear will be transported to our beach camps by boat, ensuring your kayak is light and easy to paddle. Delicious meals inspired by Mexican cuisine will be prepared by your guides, offering a unique taste of Baja California.

dayInfo.description: Arrive in La Paz - After flying into La Paz, make your way to the hotel (not included) and spend the afternoon exploring the town at your leisure. Dinner is at a restaurant of your choice and we highly recommend a sunset stroll along the Malecon. In the evening, you’ll meet your guides for an orientation meeting in the lobby of the 7 Crown Centro Hotel. Accommodations: Not Included. Meals: Not Included.

Isla Espiritu Santo - After breakfast, we’ll board a panga to be transported to Isla Espiritu Santo. Here, you will learn the basics of paddling and safety in the water from your guides before embarking on your first paddle to our campsite. All of the heavier gear, food, and water will be transported by panga, ensuring your kayak is light and easy to manage. Accommodations: Beach Camping. Meals: Lunch, Dinner.

Explore Isla Espiritu Santo - Rise to the smell of freshly brewed coffee or tea as you watch the day’s first rays illuminate the island. Following a hearty breakfast, we’ll head out on a morning paddle, with most days including around four hours of kayaking, including floating rest stops. Each day we will head to a new campsite, ensuring you get to explore as much of the area as possible. In the afternoons, there will be plenty of opportunities to go snorkeling on the surrounding reefs and hiking the island’s arroyo trails, with your knowledgeable guides sharing the natural history of the area. Alternatively, you may opt to simply relax on the beach and marvel at the changing light as the sun sinks towards the water. In the evenings, you’ll be treated to exceptional stargazing, with an almost complete lack of light pollution in the area. If you’re lucky, you may even witness blue bioluminescence glowing in the shallow waters. Accommodations: Beach Camping. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner.

Los Islotes - This morning we will travel by panga to see the colony of sea lions that inhabit Los Islotes and snorkel amongst them. This is an incredible experience, with many of the pups incredibly curious and eager to interact. The panga will then transport you back to La Paz where you will have time to refresh with a shower and enjoy a walk along the Malecon. In the evening, we will meet for a farewell dinner at a harbour-facing restaurant. Accommodations: Not Included. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch.

*Optional additional day in La Paz - While some guests may opt to fly home today, you can extend your stay to experience snorkeling with whale sharks during a morning expedition. As the world’s largest fish, these immense creatures can reach lengths of up to 42 feet. Each year between October and April, they migrate to the shallow waters of La Paz’s bay to feed on the abundance of plankton in the area. Accommodations: Not Included. Meals: Lunch.

*Optional alternative departure - With no scheduled activities, you are free to depart La Paz at a time that suits you, ensuring you get to the airport at least two hours before departure. If you’re flying out of Cabo (SJD), make sure you allow adequate time for the shuttle to get you there.

tourName: Highlights of Mexico small group holiday
generalInfo:
From the captivating capital to the sun-soaked Caribbean coast, get an introduction to Mexico on this whistle-stop tour. Journey through the country's vast history, uncovering Mayan gems including Palenque and Chichen Itza as well as the charming Colonial town of San Cristobal. Finish up on the Yucatan Peninsula, where we combine ruins with a side of relaxation, capping it off with a night in Playa del Carmen.

Visit archaeological wonders - Discover bucket-list sites like Chichen Itza, one of the new Seven Wonders of the World.
Explore colonial icons - Walk through the colourful markets of the picturesque city, San Cristobal de las Casas.
See the Sumidero Canyon - Take to the water on a boat trip through this towering gorge, spotting wildlife along the way.

dayInfo.title: Join tour in Mexico City
dayInfo.description: : Our tour starts today in Mexico City, the capital of Mexico and the bustling heart and soul of the country. The city is a patchwork of historic landmarks, buildings and the largest number of museums in the world. Due to the number of evening flights into the international airport, our tour leader will meet you on the morning of day two for a welcome meeting. Look out for a message in the hotel reception with timings and other details for the day. There are no activities planned today, so you're free to arrive at any time. If you'd like to receive an airport transfer today, you'll need to arrive into Mexico City International Airport (MEX) which is around a 30-minute to one-hour drive from the hotel. If your flight arrives earlier in the day, you might like to have a stroll around Alameda Central, Mexico City's oldest municipal park, or visit the Templo Mayor Museum, which is known for its exhibits relating to the Aztec civilization.

dayInfo.title: Visit the Teotihuacan Pyramids, tour of Mexico City
dayInfo.description: : We'll dive right into Mexico City's history today and head to the mysterious pyramids of Teotihuacan. Although it was abandoned in the thirteenth century, the site was once the largest city in the Americas with 100,000 inhabitants. Its influence continued through Middle America, and Mayan craftsmen borrowed its decorative motifs and building designs. Centuries later the Aztecs referred to Teotihuacan as 'the Place of the Gods', hinting at its importance. Afterward, we'll return to the downtown district for a walking tour of the Zocalo; the main square that has been a cornerstone in public gatherings since ancient times. The National Palace is located on the east side of the square - the President lives here as his permanent residence and we'll take a look at it from the outside, along with the grand metropolitan cathedral. Many of these key sights were built on top of Tenochtitlan, the old Aztec capital.

dayInfo.title: Fly to Tuxtla Airport, boat trip through Sumidero Canyon en-route to San Cristobal
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll fly to Tuxtla airport, in the state of Chiapas, and set off for Sumidero Canyon, a unique rift 41 kilometres long and up to 1000 metres deep, cut by the Rio Grijalva. This is where, in the 16th century, 1000 Chiapa peoples allegedly committed suicide rather than submit to Spanish rule. We'll take a trip on a speed boat to fully appreciate the towering gorge, before driving approximately two hours up a scenic mountain road to San Cristobal de las Casas, a small colonial and indigenous town located high in the tree-lined Chiapas range. At 2210 metres above sea level, it can get quite cold here at night, so it's worth packing an extra layer.

dayInfo.title: Visit indigenous villages, free afternoon in San Cristobal
dayInfo.description: : The indigenous groups from the surrounding hills fill the town and marketplace with their colourful dress including the distinctive Tzotzil community who still retain much of their Mayan customs and language. Today, we'll be visiting San Juan Chamula and Zinacantan, indigenous villages close to San Cristobal that practise an interesting blend of Catholicism and traditional Maya beliefs. This area is famous for its bright textiles and weavings in intricate designs. You might like to pick up souvenirs here during our free time this afternoon. Much like Oaxaca, San Cristobal is a charming town to explore on foot and also has its fair share of museums. The Na Bolom, House of the Jaguar, is dedicated to the preservation of the Lacandón tribe and displays many of their artefacts, while the Textiles Centre is a superb showcase of the weaving traditions found both in Chiapas as well as the rest of Mexico and Central America. There are also museums dedicated to amber and jade, that not only display historical pieces, but also give an understanding of the importance of these materials to the ancient civilisations.

dayInfo.title: Travel to Palenque
dayInfo.description: : Leaving the highlands behind us, today we have a long driving day ahead of us, approximately eight hours plus stops. The road is slow and winding, but there are scenic views as we descend to the jungles of Palenque. We'll be driving via the town of Villahermosa, where we'll stop for lunch.

dayInfo.title: Discover the Mayan site of Palenque, continue to Campeche
dayInfo.description: : Today's guided visit to the ruins of Palenque is one of the highlights of our tour of Mexico. Palenque is both a fascinating and important site and we'll explore it in depth with a guide. Once the choking forest was cleared, the ruins revealed the tomb of the high priest Pakal, his body adorned with a marvellous jade death mask - one of the most prized relics of the Mayan culture, discovered only in 1952. The entire site, shrouded by the steamy rainforest, has an aura of deep mystery. After our visit, we'll continue to the colonial city of Campeche, around a five-hour drive away (350 kilometres). In the early evening, we'll take a stroll to explore on foot. This UNESCO World Heritage-listed city was constantly besieged by pirates and so is the only walled city in Mexico. We'll take time to get an impression of the walled ramparts, narrow cobblestoned roads, boulevard and pastel coloured buildings on arrival.

dayInfo.title: Visit Uxmal and drive to Merida
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll visit Uxmal, one of the Yucatan's most underrated ancient sites to those in the know. Encircled by hills, Uxmal is expansive in its design with majestic palaces and pyramids, and long geometrical friezes that rank among the most splendid examples of ancient American Art. The incredible Pyramid of the Magician and the beautiful Governor's Palace are two of the finest examples of Mayan art found in MesoAmerica. Later in the day, we'll drive to Merida, famed for its Spanish-Moorish style architecture, where we'll have time to wander the narrow streets watching the horse-drawn carriages rattle past. Our total driving time today will be approximately three and a half hours.

dayInfo.title: Explore Chichen Itza and continue to Playa del Carmen
dayInfo.description: : This morning we'll visit the ruins of Chichen Itza. Founded in AD432, re-founded in 987 and conquered by the Toltecs in the 10th century, the culture of the Maya and the Toltec gradually fused. The pyramids, palaces, temples and ballcourt (where death was the penalty for defeat) are adorned with astonishing sculptures. Under the pressure of the civil war, the great monuments deteriorated and the Maya civilisation collapsed. Chichen Itza remains one of the most outstanding sites in the Americas, and its main pyramid was named the Seventh New Wonder of the World in 2007. We'll have a lengthy visit here, before setting off to Playa del Carmen for our final night. Time permitting, we'll stop for a swim in one of the Yucatan's cenotes (a cenote is an underground pool naturally formed in limestone, used by the ancient Mayans as a source of water). We'll arrive in Playa del Carmen in the evening. Our total driving time for today will be approximately four and a half hours.

dayInfo.title: Trip ends in Playa del Carmen
dayInfo.description: : Our trip ends this morning at our hotel in Playa del Carmen. There are no activities planned today, so you're free to depart from Playa del Carmen at any time. If your flight is departing later in the day, luggage storage facilities are available at our hotel. If you'd like an airport transfer, you'll need to depart from Cancun Airport (CUN), which is approximately a 60-minute drive away.

tourName: Highlights of the Yucatan Peninsula tour
placesVisited: Spend a week travelling from Cancun to Tulum via Valladolid, Merida, and Chichen Itza, Share lunch with a local Maya family as you tour their farm, and learn how to make tortillas, Explore the spectacular Chichen Itza with a local historian, Swim in a limestone cenote, Visit the Celestun Bird Sanctuary and Biosphere Reserve with a local conservationist, Boat tour through the ancient Mayil trading post, Finish with a few days to unwind and sunbathe in Tulum
generalInfo:
The beauty of this Yucatan Peninsula tour is that it doesn’t simply tick off the key experiences, like Chichen Itza, swimming in a cenote, or exploring Merida. Instead, taking your time, you’ll be immersed in life here, sharing traditional homecooked meals with Maya farming families, meeting up with knowledgeable guides such as conservationists and historians, and staying in some charming boutique hotels.

Over the course of a memorable week you’ll travel from the sun-drenched Caribbean coastline of Puerto Morelos to Tulum, in the engaging company of a small group (maximum group size 12) and a dedicated tour leader, who is there to ensure the trip runs smoothly. Along the way, you’ll learn how to make an authentic tortilla, take a dip in a beautiful limestone cenote, uncover the secrets of ancient Maya civilisation at Chichen Itza and Tulum, and spend a few nights in a hotel that was once a 17th century mansion.

Following a guided tour of historic downtown Merida with its plazas, markets, and murals, you’ll head to the Celestun Bird Sanctuary, a biosphere reserve, with a local conservationist as your guide. Sixty-six million years ago, an asteroid strike on the Yucatan Peninsula is thought to have wiped out almost all of the dinosaurs on earth, but their winged brethren survived, and evolved into the many species inhabiting these mangroves. Visit between November and March, and you may see crowds of flamingos painting the scenery a vivid shade of pink.

From Merida you continue to Tulum and its vast, oceanside archaeological site – one of the most renowned in all Central America. But not before a day amid the ancient ruins of Muyil, once a Maya trading post. Here you’ll take to a boat for a river tour with members of the local community as your guides, for a relaxed and informative cruise – plus a swim, of course.

Arriving in Tulum you’ll take your leave of the group and your tour leader with a farewell meal – and a chance to take one final leap into Mexican cuisine – the seafood in this part of the country is divine.

Staying in locally owned hotels, eating at local restaurants recommended by your tour leader, and being entertained by a succession of local guides, on this trip you cannot fail to make a positive difference to the places you visit. Wondering if you can find a Mexico cultural trip with a reassuringly responsible flavour? Yes, you Yucatan!

dayInfo.title: Playa Del Carmen.
dayInfo.description: Bienvenidos! Welcome to Mexico. Your adventure begins in Playa del Carmen – a coastal resort town on the Yucatan Peninsula, known for its turquoise waters and nightlife. You’ll be met at Cancun International Airport and transferred to your hotel. Here, you’ll meet your local leader and fellow group members at your welcome meeting at 6 pm tonight. If you arrive early, you might like to stroll along pedestrian avenue while perusing handmade hammocks, jewellery and crafts. After your meeting, head into town for your first dinner in Mexico at a local restaurant.

dayInfo.title: Valladolid.
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, depart Playa del Carmen and head to the secluded Laguna Chabela. Here, you’ll meet a local Maya family who have lived here for generations. Gain a deeper understanding of their way of life as you walk through the low jungle full of medicinal plants, see what they grow and learn how they live off the land. Watch a demonstration on how to make delicious tortillas in the Coba style with the family matriarch then sit down to a traditional lunch prepared by hand using a mortar and pestle found in the nearby ruins, still used after 1000 years. You’ll feel like you’ve travelled back in time, with stones from ancient Maya structures emerging from the jungle and the sounds of birds as your backdrop. In the afternoon, continue to the city of Valladolid, known for its pastel-coloured buildings. Set on the city’s main square, your hotel was converted from a 16th century house and offers a perfect base for your explorations.

dayInfo.title: Merida - Chichen Itza.
dayInfo.description: This morning will be spent exploring the complex of Chichen Itza. Named as one of the new Seven Wonders of the World, Chichen Itza is considered the most important archaeological vestige of the Maya-Toltec civilisation in Yucatan by UNESCO. Meet with a local guide for a tour to uncover the secrets of what is perhaps the most famous Maya site, dominated by the Temple of Kukulkan, or El Castillo – a Mesoamerican step-pyramid. After, you’ll have a home-cooked lunch with a local family in the town of Piste. Tuck into a traditional Pibil feast – a Maya style of cooking that involves barbecuing underground, which the family have perfected over generations. After lunch, visit a local cenote for a swim. These limestone sinkholes were viewed by the Maya as doorways to the underworld. Continue to Merida – founded in 1542, this city is the Yucatan capital and retains much of its old-world charm. Your Feature Stay accommodation for the next three evenings is in the historic Hotel Casa Lucia. Spacious rooms feature traditional touches, surrounding a courtyard that features a swimming pool.

dayInfo.title: Merida.
dayInfo.description: This morning, you’ll join your leader on a walking tour of downtown Merida to learn more about the Maya heritage of the town. Visit the market for a look at local life and stop by the city museum, Montejo's House and the cathedral. Step inside the Palacio del Gobierno to admire the murals by Fernando Castro Pacheco – a famous Mexican artist from Merida. The paintings depict the history of the city and interactions between the Maya and the Spanish. The afternoon is free for further discoveries – you might like to relax in the green and shady Plaza Grande or browse the outdoor market selling Maya replicas. Regroup for dinner at a local restaurant serving up Yucatan specialties – the sopa de lima (lime soup) is especially delicious here.

dayInfo.title: Merida.
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, you’ll head out for another Exclusive Experience at the Ría Celestún Biosphere Reserve and Bird Sanctuary. One of the first places migratory birds arrive for the winter, the reserve offers a birdwatching experience like no other. Tour the area by small boat while you learn about its unique flora and fauna. Look out for the Yucatan woodpecker, Mexican sheartail, tropical mockingbird and depending on the season (usually December to March), you might witness the thousands of flamingos streaking across the landscape. Hop off the boat for a quick walk to view bubbling springs then cruise back through the mangrove canals. Stop in a fishing town for some time for lunch – maybe grab some fresh seafood and eat it with your toes in the sand. Take a dip in the Gulf of Mexico before returning to Merida for a free afternoon.

dayInfo.title: Tulum.
dayInfo.description: Depart Merida this morning and head towards Muyil, stopping off for lunch in the village of Coba. Continue to the virtually unknown Muyil Archaeologic Site – this ancient Maya trading post is one of the oldest once-inhabited sites in the country, with a history stretching back to 350 BC. Explore the ruins with your leader who will explain what life here once looked like. Next, head to the banks of the Maya River and board a small boat to explore the canals and lagoons of the Sian Ka'an biosphere. One of the largest protected areas in Mexico, this UNESCO World Heritage site covers more than 400,000 hectares of land, lagoon and marine areas, including countless flora and fauna. You’ll be joined by guides from the local community who will help you get the most out of this experience. Admire the ruins on the riverbanks before disembarking in the waters of the ancient Mayan mangrove canals, where you’ll experience a natural ‘lazy river’ and float through the peaceful canals in a slow but steady current. After 45 minutes of floating, carry on to Tulum.

dayInfo.title: Tulum.
dayInfo.description: In the morning, head to the Tulum archaeological site and learn about the history of the ruins and their views of the ocean. One of the last cities built by the Maya, your leader will paint a picture of how life played out here as you explore the complex against the ocean backdrop. Spend the afternoon soaking up the sun at a beach club, where you can swim in the Caribbean Sea or nap in a comfortable lounge chair. Tonight, dine at one of Tulum’s best restaurants. With laid back vibes and inspired by the freshest local produce and seafood, this final dinner with your newfound friends will certainly be one to remember.

dayInfo.title: Tulum.
dayInfo.description: Your adventure comes to an end after breakfast this morning. If you would like to spend some more time in Tulum, just speak to your booking agent ahead of time to organise additional accommodation.

tourName: Mexico 10 Day tour
generalInfo:
Ready for an adventure bursting with vibrant culture, breathtaking landscapes, and unforgettable experiences? Our 10-day Mexico tour takes you from the lively streets of Mexico City to the crystal-clear cenotes of the Yucatán. Cheer on masked wrestlers at a thrilling Lucha Libre match, catch a sunset surf in Puerto Escondido, and swim in glowing bioluminescent waters. Dive into Oaxacan traditions with a hands-on mole cooking class and mezcal tasting before exploring the ancient wonders of Chichén Itzá and Tulum. Whether you’re cycling through Mayan ruins, dancing salsa, or unwinding on pristine beaches, this trip is packed with epic moments. Adventure, history, and incredible food—Mexico is waiting!

If this trip seems like something of interest for you, get in touch and we can build an itinerary around the following inclusions:

Accommodation:

- Includes hostel accommodation throughout your tour.
- All accommodation is simple, but clean and comfortable.

Transport:

- All local transport throughout your tour, including buses and an internal flight.

Guiding:
- One amazing Adventure Leader for your entire tour.

Activities:

- Lucha Libre, traditional Mexican wrestling (Mexico City) 
- Walking tour of Mexico City (Mexico City) 
- Informal Spanish lesson (Mexico City) 
- Surf lesson (Puerto Escondido) 
- Alebrijes workshop (on route to Oaxaca) 
- Cooking class (Oaxaca) 
- Hierve el Agua day tour incl. Visit to Tule tree and Milta Ancient Ruins (Oaxaca) 
- Mezcal tasting (Oaxaca) 
- Salsa lesson (Oaxaca) 
- Flight from Oaxaca to Cancun 
- Chichén Itzá visit 
- Visit & swim in local Cenote (Tulum) 
- Guided bike tour (Tulum)

dayInfo.description: Mexico City: Get ready for an exciting start to your adventure as you meet your Adventure Leader in the hotel lounge this afternoon for a trip briefing. You’ll get all the details on your journey ahead, plus top tips for staying safe while exploring Central America. Then, it’s time to dive straight into the action—Mexican style! Your first night kicks off with Lucha Libre, the country’s electrifying take on wrestling. Expect dramatic moves, flamboyant costumes, and legendary masked wrestlers putting on an unforgettable show. This is Mexico City at its most thrilling! Arriving early? Here’s how to make the most of your extra time: History buff? Visit the ancient pyramids of Teotihuacán, a UNESCO World Heritage site home to the awe-inspiring Pyramids of the Sun and the Moon. Want a local experience? Head to Xochimilco, where you’ll float along colorful canals on a traditional trajinera (gondola). Enjoy mariachi music, delicious Mexican street food, and maybe even a tequila or two! No matter how you choose to kick off your adventure, get ready for an incredible journey through Mexico!

Mexico City: What better way to kick off your adventure than with a walking tour of Mexico City’s most iconic landmarks? Stroll through the historic Zócalo Main Square, marvel at the grandeur of the Metropolitan Cathedral, take in the stunning murals at the National Palace, and uncover the ancient ruins of the Templo Mayor—a fascinating glimpse into the city’s Aztec past. After a morning of exploration, it’s time to fuel up with a delicious local lunch before switching gears to a Spanish crash course led by your Adventure Leader. Learn key phrases that’ll help you connect with locals and enhance your travel experience—because ordering tacos in Spanish just hits different! The Afternoon Is Yours—How Will You Spend It? Cycle to Chapultepec Castle – Rent a bike and cruise over to Chapultepec Park, home to the only royal castle in the Americas. Once an imperial palace, a battlefield, and now a museum, this historic site offers breathtaking panoramic views of the city. Prefer a more relaxed approach? Hop in an Uber and take a leisurely ride to the castle instead! As the sun sets, gather with your group for an evening of authentic Mexican cuisine. Savour bold flavours, soak in the vibrant atmosphere, and cap it all off with tequila or mezcal—the choice (and the consequences) are yours!

Puerto Escondido: Rise and shine! This morning, we’ll catch an early flight to the breathtaking coastal town of Puerto Escondido, arriving just in time for lunch. Once we land, the afternoon is yours to spend as you wish. Beach time? Dive into the crystal-clear waters, soak up the sun, and unwind on the golden sands. Poolside vibes? Kick back with your travel crew and enjoy some well-earned relaxation at the hostel. Sunset Surf Session – Ride the Waves in Paradise As the late afternoon rolls in, we’ll head to the beach for an unforgettable surf lesson at sunset! Puerto Escondido is a world-famous surfing hotspot, and there’s no better place to check "learn to surf" off your bucket list. What to Expect: Learn surf basics and pop-up techniques from a professional coach Practice on the sand before hitting the waves Ride the ocean under a golden sunset The Night is Yours – What’s the Move? Enjoy fresh seafood at a local restaurant Sip cocktails at a beachfront bar with stunning ocean views Experience La Punta’s buzzing nightlife and dance under the stars Whether you're looking for laid-back beach vibes or an unforgettable night out, Puerto Escondido has it all!

Puerto Escondido: Today is all about relaxation, exploration, and adventure – the choice is yours! Chill Mode: - Soak up the sun on Puerto Escondido’s stunning beaches - Wander through this bohemian coastal town and explore its laid-back charm - Discover nearby hidden beaches for a more secluded escape Adventure Mode: - Dolphin & Whale Watching Tour (seasonal) - Spot playful dolphins, majestic humpback whales, sea turtles, and other marine life - Enjoy breathtaking views of the Pacific Ocean while basking in the sun A Night to Remember – Bioluminescent Lagoon Experience As night falls, get ready for one of nature’s most magical phenomena – the Manialtepec Lagoon. What to Expect: Swim through glowing waters as bioluminescent creatures light up around you A once-in-a-lifetime experience straight out of a fairy tale A true main character moment you’ll never forget Note: This activity is unavailable on nights surrounding a full moon due to visibility. Or… Keep the Night Going! If you’d rather keep the party vibes alive, hit up Puerto Escondido’s legendary nightlife with your travel crew. From beach bars to rooftop parties, the energy here is electric! Whatever you choose, today is all about making unforgettable memories in paradise!

Oaxaca: This morning, we set off early for our next destination—Oaxaca (pronounced Wahaca), a city known for its deep Indigenous heritage, vibrant festivals, and colonial architecture. Along the way, you’ll have the chance to get creative by making your own alebrijes, the intricately painted wooden creatures inspired by traditional Mexican folk art. Arriving in Oaxaca in the early afternoon, your Adventure Leader will meet you before you check into your hostel. The afternoon is yours to explore at your own pace. A great place to start is the botanical gardens, which showcase a stunning variety of native Mexican plant species. Later, join your fellow travelers for a hands-on cooking class, where you’ll learn to prepare a classic Oaxacan dish—mole. This rich, flavorful sauce is a staple of the region, known for its perfect balance of smoky, sweet, and spicy flavors. With your culinary skills sharpened, the evening is yours to enjoy. You might choose to browse the artisan markets, relax at a rooftop bar, or experience live music and traditional dance performances in this lively and culturally rich city.

Hierve el Agua: This morning, we rise early and head straight to the iconic Hierve el Agua, but not before making a stop to see the famous Tule tree—widely regarded as the world’s widest tree! This ancient Montezuma cypress is over 2,000 years old and has a diameter of 14 meters (46 feet), which is roughly the same width as a tennis court or an adult blue whale! Next, we’ll continue our journey to Hierve el Agua, located about 70 km east of Oaxaca. This stunning natural site is known for its mineral-rich rock formations that resemble cascading waterfalls. We’ll take time to explore the area and, if you wish, take a refreshing dip in the spring-fed pools. On our way back to Oaxaca, we’ll immerse ourselves in authentic Mexican culture with two unforgettable stops. First, we’ll visit the Mitla Ancient Ruins, a Zapotec archaeological site famous for its intricate geometric mosaics, well-preserved temples, and its history as a sacred burial ground. Then, we’ll dive into a mezcal tasting session, where you’ll learn about this smoky spirit and its traditional production methods, all guided by an expert. In the evening, it’s time for a fun and lively Mexican experience—salsa dancing! Join your group for an exciting salsa class where you’ll learn the vibrant rhythms and energetic moves that define this cultural dance.

Oaxaca to Tulum: This morning, we'll head to the airport for our next exciting destination—Tulum! After a flight to Cancun, we’ll take a bus transfer to Tulum, arriving around 3pm. The rest of the day is yours to enjoy at your leisure, but if the weather is perfect, you may want to join a sunset sailing tour. (Feel free to email us for more details.)

Tulum: This morning, we’ll set off to explore Chichén Itzá, an awe-inspiring ancient Mayan city and UNESCO World Heritage Site. Home to the iconic El Castillo pyramid, this remarkable site also showcases other stunning Mayan structures that reveal the region’s rich cultural and architectural history. After soaking in the grandeur of Chichén Itzá, we’ll make our way to a local, community-run cenote. These natural limestone sinkholes, once considered sacred by the Mayans, are perfect for a refreshing swim in their vibrant blue waters, surrounded by lush, natural beauty. Next, we’ll head to Valladolid, a picturesque colonial town known for its colorful streets, historic charm, and deep Mayan roots. After a delightful lunch, we’ll continue on our journey back to Tulum. As the evening draws near, consider joining your group to watch the sunset at one of the beach bars or take some time to explore the lively atmosphere of Tulum’s downtown.

Tulum: Today is all about exploration, and what better way to do it than by bike? In the morning, we’ll embark on a guided bike tour through Tulum, where you’ll visit the stunning ancient Mayan ruins perched above the sea. Along the way, we’ll pedal through the vibrant town before reaching the beach for a refreshing dip in the crystal-clear waters. The afternoon is yours to enjoy however you wish! Our local experts recommend the following options to make the most of your time in Tulum: -For a relaxing vibe – cycle back to the hostel for some downtime. -For water enthusiasts – take a snorkel in a beautiful cenote, one of our top picks. -For nature lovers – embark on a guided boat tour through Sian Ka’an at sunset. For beach lovers - lounge on the pristine sands of Playa Paraíso. As evening sets in, why not head to Tulum Pueblo for a delicious meal? Treat yourself to affordable tacos or traditional Yucatán dishes. Finish off the night at Batey Mojito & Guarapo Bar, where you can enjoy a mojito and live music, toasting to another unforgettable day with your travel companions!

Farewell: This morning, your Mexico adventure concludes in Tulum! Bid farewell to your Adventure Leader! If you need airport transfers or would like to arrange post-night accommodations, we can help! Please contact us for more details. Safe travels!

tourName: Mexico 13 day tour, through the Yucatan
generalInfo:
Playa del Carmen - Chichen Itza - Merida - Campeche - Palenque - Tulum

The Yucatan Peninsula is a vast and varied region with lots to discover. Laze on palm-fringed beaches, explore ancient Mayan ruins and snorkel in the sparkling waters of the cenotes. Whether man-made or natural, there are lots of gems to uncover in this part of Mexico. You’ll travel by bus over two weeks, past colonial facades and rugged coastlines, stopping at towns along the way to get a real feel for Mexican culture, cuisine and cervezas!

dayInfo.description: Welcome to the Mexican riviera: Touch down in Cancun and head straight to Playa del Carmen where you’ll see miles of Caribbean coastline, that will instantly initiate that holiday feeling! Here, you’ll meet our local team, get your bearings, and maybe grab a margarita in your pool-side hotel. You’ll have time to go shopping and bar and restaurant hopping and, before you know it, it’ll be time to move inland to one of Mexico's most iconic ancient sites: Chichen Itza.

The Mayan route to Chichen Itza: You’ll hop on a comfortably air-conditioned bus across the Yucatan peninsula to Campeche, on the Gulf of Mexico. On your first stop, immerse yourself in the rich history of the ancient Mayans in Chichen Itza, an enchanting glimpse into the life of Mayan civilisation. From Chichen Itza, continue to Mérida, a colonial beauty with tree-lined plazas, live music spilling from doorways, and some seriously good food. You'll venture out to swim in a cenote, those ethereal sinkholes along the Yucatan's limestone crust, that create natural swimming pools surrounded by jungle. Next stop: Campeche, a former pirate stronghold on the Gulf of Mexico. Its UNESCO-protected old town is all pastel-colored colonial buildings and cobbled streets within ancient walls. We've left your time here unstructured, just explore, eat well, and soak up the atmosphere of this often-overlooked gem.

Passage to Palenque: The bus journey to Palenque takes you deeper into tropical terrain. The town itself won't win beauty contests, but what lies just beyond it will take your breath away: emerging from dense jungle rises the dramatic Palenque ruins. After exploring at your own pace, cool off at the Roberto Barrios waterfalls before heading back to your pool-side hotel to relax.

Tulum, Mayan ruins on palm beach: Your final stop brings you full circle to the Caribbean coast, but Tulum has a very different vibe from where you started. Here, ancient Mayan temples sit perched on clifftops above turquoise water, and golden sands. You're also close enough to explore the jungle ruins of Cobá if you fancy one last adventure. Mostly though, this is your time to decompress, cycle to the beach, eat fresh ceviche, and reflect on a journey that's taken you from Caribbean shores through colonial cities to jungle-clad ruins and back again.

tourName: Mexico 2 week holiday, tailor made
generalInfo:
Embark on a culturally rich journey through Mexico, blending archaeology, local encounters, and natural wonders. This adventure takes you from bustling cities to serene jungles, immersing you in the country’s history, heritage, and hospitality.

Begin in Mexico City, a captivating blend of ancient and modern. Explore the historic center with a passionate local guide, then head to the artistic neighborhood of Coyoacán, where cobblestone streets and colonial charm lead you to Frida Kahlo’s legendary Blue House. Dive into her world and learn about the life and legacy of one of Mexico’s most iconic artists.

Next, visit the awe-inspiring pyramids of Teotihuacán, a sacred site once known as the “City of the Gods.” Walk along the Avenue of the Dead and climb the Pyramids of the Sun and Moon as you uncover the mysteries of this ancient civilization.

Continue to the culturally vibrant cities of Puebla and Oaxaca, where culinary delights, traditional markets, and indigenous art await. Taste mole and mezcal, meet local artisans, and explore UNESCO-listed architecture that tells the story of Mexico’s colonial past and indigenous roots.

Then, fly to the Yucatán Peninsula, where the secrets of the Maya come alive. Discover majestic archaeological sites such as Ek Balam, Chichén Itzá, and Uxmal — each offering a different window into the complexity and brilliance of Maya civilization.

Beyond the ruins, connect with local communities through immersive experiences. In small Maya villages, join hands-on workshops like tortilla-making, weaving, or crafting dreamcatchers. Explore hidden cenotes tucked deep in the jungle and learn about Melipona bees, sacred to the Maya for their honey and ecological importance.

Throughout your journey, you’ll support locally-owned hotels and businesses, such as a family-run guesthouse in Puerto Morelos, and use a Mexican rental car company to minimize external impact. Each step contributes to the local economy and the preservation of Mexico’s cultural and natural heritage.

This itinerary is more than a trip — it’s a meaningful exchange with the people and places that make Mexico truly magical.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to Mexico City, the capital and largest city of Mexico, renowned for its rich history and culture. It blends pre-Hispanic, colonial, and modern eras, offering travelers an endless array of places to visit and a diverse gastronomy. Upon your arrival at Mexico City Airport, a private transfer will be waiting to take you to your hotel. On your way to your first destination, time to relax and enjoy your first moments under the Mexican sky.

Take the day to explore the vibrant heart of Mexico City at your own pace. Morning: Start with a leisurely stroll through the historic Zócalo, where you can admire the impressive Metropolitan Cathedral and the National Palace with its famous Diego Rivera murals. Midday: Wander through the nearby streets to discover local artisan shops and enjoy a traditional Mexican lunch in one of the many authentic eateries. Afternoon: Visit the Palacio de Bellas Artes, an architectural gem showcasing both Art Nouveau and Art Deco styles, or explore the lively Alameda Central Park. Evening: Unwind in the trendy neighborhood of Roma or Condesa, known for its charming cafes, boutique shops, and vibrant nightlife.

Explore the charming and historic neighborhood of Coyoacán at your own pace. Morning: Begin with a leisurely walk through the Plaza Hidalgo and Jardín Centenario, soaking in the colonial architecture and vibrant street life. Stop for a coffee at one of the quaint local cafes. Midday: Visit the iconic Frida Kahlo Museum (La Casa Azul) to learn about the life and work of the renowned artist. Alternatively, explore the nearby Leon Trotsky Museum for a glimpse into revolutionary history. Afternoon: Stroll through the Coyoacán Market, where you can sample local snacks like churros, esquites, and tostadas, or shop for artisanal crafts and souvenirs. Evening: Unwind in one of the traditional cantinas or enjoy some live music at a local bar.

Today, you will visit one of the most impressive archaeological sites in Mexico and discover it in a unique way. Around 8 AM, you will be personally picked up at your hotel and head towards the archaeological site, located about 1 to 1.5 hours away from the city (depending on traffic). Upon arrival, you will receive a welcome kit including a bottle of water, disinfectant wipes, and snacks. To begin your walking tour, your guide will share the mysteries of this ancient city, where you will admire structures such as the Temple of the Feathered Serpent and the impressive Pyramids of the Sun and the Moon. At the end of your visit, you will take a short break to enjoy a coffee. After recharging, you will hop on a bike to explore the Teotihuacán Valley surrounding the archaeological site, as well as a cave. This part of the tour is estimated to last about 2 hours. Once the bike tour is over, you will return your bike and head for lunch. Around 4 PM, you will set off towards Puebla. Included Transport, guide, entrance, meal

Today, enjoy a walking tour of the historic center of Puebla, a UNESCO World Heritage site. You will begin by admiring the impressive cathedral and the Chapel of the Rosary, undoubtedly one of the most splendid examples of the New Hispanic Baroque. Next, visit a Talavera workshop (ceramics), one of Mexico's most representative crafts, and the Palafoxiana Library, a center of universal knowledge and one of the first libraries on the American continent. Its variety and bibliographic richness earned it the title of Memory of the World by UNESCO, a true gem of Puebla. During your stroll through the beautiful streets of the historic center, you will also see other iconic sites of the city, such as Calle de los Dulces, the famous Barrio del Artista and Barrio de los Sapos, as well as the El Parián artisan market. This is a wonderful tour that will allow you to admire the historic center of this beautiful city through its neighborhoods, chapels, and activities. Included Guide and entrance.

Today, you will depart from the city of Puebla to the city of Oaxaca. A private transfer will take you to CAPU (Puebla’s bus terminal), where you will catch the bus to Oaxaca. Upon arrival, head to your hotel.

Today, your English-speaking local guide will pick you up for a tour (approximately 8 hours) combining archaeology, craftsmanship, and nature. The tour will begin 10 km outside of Oaxaca city, after a 20-minute transfer. Your first stop will be Santa María del Tule to see the ancient Tule Tree, a Montezuma cypress around two thousand years old, renowned for having the most massive trunk in the world. Next, you will be transferred for about 1.5 hours to Hierve el Agua, a park known for its rock formations that resemble waterfalls. You will have the chance to explore the area and swim in the mineral-rich cold springs while enjoying panoramic views of the surrounding mountain landscape. Afterward, you will head to the Mitla Archaeological Site to admire and learn about the intricate geometric designs in the decorative walls. Following a 30-minute break, you will head to Teotitlán del Valle, where you will visit the House of Wool Weavers to discover the entire process of spinning, weaving, and dyeing wool. Finally, you will visit the Mezcal Distillery (Palenque de Mezcal), where you will have the opportunity to taste different types of mezcal and learn about their production process. After a full day of activities, you will return to the city of Oaxaca. Included Transport, guide, entrance, stands, parking, and mezcal tasting.

Today, a private transfer will take you to Oaxaca Airport. Take your flight to Cancun! Upon arrival at Cancun Airport, head to the car rental desk. A shuttle will take you to the agency located just a few minutes from the airport, where you will meet our English-speaking local agent.

Today, your English-speaking local guide will accompany you to visit Ek Balam, an archaeological site meaning "black jaguar" or "dark jaguar" in Maya. This ancient city was highly significant as it hosted political meetings, and to this day, its secrets remain mysterious. Upon arrival, you will see the impressive structures surrounded by nature. At the beginning of the visit, your guide will explain the geographical layout of the site. You will head to the court, where the Mayans played the famous ball game, a characteristic sport of this culture. Then, you will climb to the top of the Acropolis Pyramid to enjoy the panoramic view of the surrounding area. Continue towards the twin pyramids and the oval palace, where you will be amazed by the majestic serpents in hieroglyphs and the stelae carved into the stone blocks, making you feel as if you've been transported back to the fascinating Maya era. The concentration of pyramids in a small area will allow you to fully enjoy each part of the site in a reasonable amount of time. Next, you will embark on a visit that will immerse you in the rich history, culture, traditions, and customs of this community. This interactive experience will allow you to see and learn the art of hammock weaving, a traditional craft of the Yucatán. You will have the opportunity to participate in the manufacturing process. After that, you will visit a second Maya house, where you will discover the embroidery of colorful clothes and have the chance to sew a souvenir piece to take home. The experience will culminate with the preparation of corn tortillas, where you will knead the dough with your own hands and learn how to make the delicious tortillas that are a staple in the daily diet of the Maya people. In about two and a half hours, you will be fully immersed in Maya culture and gain first-hand knowledge of their traditions. Included Entrance fee to the Archaeological Site of Ek Balam - For foreigners Guide Food Guide and 3 workshops.

Discover the heritage of the ancient Maya civilization at the Chichén Itzá Archaeological Site. An English-speaking local guide will take you on a tour of approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes of the most iconic buildings, including the Kukulcan Pyramid, the Temple of the Warriors, and the Observatory. As you walk around the site, you will be able to admire the intricate sculptures and reliefs depicting the life and beliefs of the ancient Mayas. With its impressive architecture and design, Chichén Itzá is one of the most remarkable sites in the Yucatán Peninsula. It's a great opportunity to learn about Maya culture and its legacy in world history. After your visit, you will head towards Merida! Included Guide. INAH fee: Chichén Itzá AS - Foreigners AAFY fee: Chichén Itzá AS - Foreigners

Discover the vibrant culture and colonial charm of Mérida at your own pace. Morning: Start your day with a leisurely stroll along Paseo de Montejo, Mérida’s grand avenue lined with historic mansions. Stop for breakfast at a local café and take in the architecture. Midday: Visit the Plaza Grande, the heart of the city, and explore the Cathedral of San Ildefonso, one of the oldest cathedrals in the Americas. Don’t miss the Palacio de Gobierno to see its striking murals depicting Yucatán’s history. Afternoon: Wander through the Lucas de Gálvez Market, where you can sample Yucatecan specialties like cochinita pibil or panuchos. Alternatively, visit the Gran Museo del Mundo Maya for an in-depth look at the region’s rich Mayan heritage. Evening: Head to the charming neighborhood of Santa Lucía to enjoy a live music performance or dinner at a local restaurant offering regional cuisine.

Today, your English-speaking local guide will take you on a tour of about one and a half hours through the architectural history of the city of Uxmal, one of the most important archaeological sites of the Maya world, whose name means "three times built." Be amazed by its low and horizontal palaces, which, in addition to having abundant decorations of detailed sculptures in the form of geometric mosaics, are arranged around courtyards or quadrangles. Legend has it that Uxmal was named after the Pyramid of the Magician, the tallest Maya construction and a representative of the architectural style characteristic of the Yucatán Peninsula, the Puuc. Although Uxmal was abandoned sometime after the 10th century, its architectural heritage has survived and remains an important part of the region's cultural heritage. Next, your second English-speaking guide will be waiting for you at the meeting point to introduce you to an interesting project of about one and a half hours, where locals seek to preserve both nature and traditional Maya culture. Here, the community members will invite you to participate in a jicara carving workshop, a fruit that is cultivated in the Yucatán Peninsula and was used to store food or water in ancient times. You will be surprised by the various types of handcrafted items that can be made with this natural fruit. Test your manual and artistic skills, as well as your creativity, so that by the end, you can take home a handcrafted object made by you. In the evening, you will stay overnight in a bungalow in Izamal. Included Guide service at Uxmal AS - 1.5h - ENG Guide and entrance fee.

Take a leisurely drive towards El Cuyo! Take your time to stroll between the ocean and the lagoon. Swim in the incredibly blue sea, have lunch at the small village restaurants, walk through the streets, and most importantly, don't forget to admire the sunset over the beach (in spring/summer) or over the lagoon (in fall/winter).

Start your day in El Cuyo by enjoying the peaceful beach, perfect for a swim or a stroll. Relax while admiring the fine sand and crystal-clear water. Next, head to a local restaurant to savor fresh ceviche or fish tacos. Afterward, wander through the village streets and visit the market to buy artisanal souvenirs. In the afternoon, try kite surfing or explore the Flamingo Lagoon by boat. For nature lovers, a trip to the island of Las Ánimas is a must. End your day with a spectacular sunset on the beach, followed by a seafood dinner by the sea. El Cuyo is a true haven of peace to recharge and enjoy nature.

Today, it will be time to say goodbye to Mexican lands! We hope you had an excellent stay and that you'll return home with plenty of memories and stars in your eyes. Depending on your flight time, head to the airport to return your rental car. See you soon for a new Mexican adventure.

tourName: Mexico and Yucatan Peninsula holiday
generalInfo:
Journey through the ancient heartland of the Aztecs, Zapotecs and Maya on our tour of Mexico and beyond. From the energy of Mexico City to the vibrance of colonial Oaxaca and the mystery of the Palenque jungle, tick off Mexico's must-sees before crossing the border into Guatemala and Belize. Get a real flavour for local life, fuelling up on tacos and tequila. Want to see Mexico at its most vibrant. Choose a Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) departure to witness the unique celebration.

Marvel at Mayan ruins - From Palenque to Tikal, get closer to Latin Americas mysterious heritage at these iconic sites.

Soak up colonial charm - Visit idyllic cities like Oaxaca and San Cristobal, soaking up local life in the Zocalos and dipping into artisanal markets.

See the Sumidero Canyon - Take to the water on a boat trip through this towering gorge, spotting wildlife along the way.

dayInfo.title: Join tour in Mexico City
dayInfo.description: : Our tour starts today in Mexico City, the capital of Mexico and the bustling heart and soul of the country. CDMX, as the city is also known, gives 'metropolis' a whole new meaning with a new landmark, museum or gallery at every turn, not to mention the countless colourful markets, cosmopolitan eateries and leafy parks. Due to the number of evening flights into the international airport, our tour leader will meet you on the morning of day two for a welcome meeting. Look out for a message in the hotel reception with timings and other details for the day. There are no activities planned today, so you're free to arrive at any time. If you'd like to receive an airport transfer today, you'll need to arrive into Mexico City International Airport (MEX) which is around a 30-minute to one-hour drive from the hotel. If your flight arrives earlier in the day, you might like to have a stroll around Alameda Central, Mexico City's oldest municipal park, or visit the Templo Mayor Museum, which is known for its exhibits relating to the Aztec civilization.

dayInfo.title: Tour of Mexico City, including Museum of Anthropology
dayInfo.description: : We'll head out to explore the city like a local this morning, on foot and by public transport. The Zocalo is the vibrant heart of the city; the main square that has been a cornerstone in public gatherings since ancient times. We'll walk down to the centre from the hotel, taking a trip to a local pasteleria en route to try some traditional sweet bread. The National Palace is located on the east side of the square - the President lives here as his permanent residence and we'll take a look at it from the outside, along with the grand metropolitan cathedral. The Zocalo also gives us our first taste of Mexico's ancient history - the well-preserved remains of the ancient Aztec Templo Mayor can be found here, right in the bustle of the downtown district. After exploring around the Zocalo, we'll hop on public transport to the sprawling Chapultepec Park, where we'll wander through to the National Anthropology Museum. One of the finest museums in the world, its exhibits give us a flavour of the country's history, which we'll delve further into during our stay. Today's city tour ends at the museum, and you can opt to spend more time exploring or head back to the centre with our tour leader. Please note, our walk will cover around 10 kilometres/6 miles, including time at the museum, so comfortable shoes are recommended.

dayInfo.title: Visit the Teotihuacan Pyramids and the Basilica de Guadalupe
dayInfo.description: : Our destination today is Teotihuacan, a mysterious complex of pyramid ruins, abandoned 13 centuries ago. En route, we'll make a stop at the Basilica de Guadalupe, an important pilgrimage site for Mexicans which has a miraculous story to tell (our tour leader will fill us in). Moving on to the Teotihuacan Pyramids, we'll take some time to explore. Once the largest city in the Americas, with 100,000 inhabitants, its influence swept through Middle America and Maya craftsmen borrowed its decorative motifs and building designs. Centuries later, the Aztecs came to call Teotihuacan 'the Place of the Gods', giving you a hint at its importance. After our visit, we'll have lunch nearby (not included) and we might have time to discover the ancient uses of agave and obsidian in a workshop and craft shop nearby. In the afternoon, we'll head back to Mexico City and, if you'd like to, there'll be the chance to climb the Torre Latinoamericana this evening - one of the tallest buildings in the city, with a panoramic viewing platform that gives views across the downtown and beyond.

dayInfo.title: Journey to Oaxaca, free time to explore the city
dayInfo.description: : Leaving the capital behind, today we'll drive south through cactus country to Oaxaca, one of the most charming colonial cities in Mexico. The drive will take around eight hours, but we'll make several stops along the way. During the latter half of our journey, we'll be treated to beautiful views out to the Sierra Madre Mountains and the cactus-covered landscape. Arriving in Oaxaca in the later afternoon, we'll get our bearings with an orientation tour. It's a captivating city with vibrant colours and charming architecture at every turn. The pedestrian street that leads up to the ornate Santo Domingo church is lined with shops, cafes, restaurants, and small artisanal markets, while the Zocalo is a social hub for local families, street vendors and entertainers come evening. Why not get a taste of local life and take a seat in one of the terrace restaurants overlooking the hubbub?

dayInfo.title: Visit the pyramids of Monte Alban, free afternoon in Oaxaca
dayInfo.description: : As with many of Mexico's colonial cities, Oaxaca was built in the 16th century using stones from ancient civilisations in the surrounding areas. Today, we'll visit Monte Alban which was built by the Zapotec people who flourished here over 1,500 years ago. This complex of temples, pyramids and enigmatic rock carvings was built on top of a hill (so expect some steep inclines and stairs on our walk). The expansive views over the Sierra Madre and the fertile valley are well worth the effort. Unlike sites like Teotihuacan, Monte Alban was lived in until the arrival of the conquistadors, as the Mixtec civilisation took over from the Zapotecs and continued its use. This afternoon, we'll have free time to explore Oaxaca. Take a walk through the historic centre and soak in the colourful buildings, dip into one of the markets to pick up souvenirs or delve further into the history of the city at one of the museums. The Museum of Cultures of Oaxaca, next to the Santo Domingo Church, is one of the best in town, housing treasures from Monte Alban within the building of an ex-convent (opening hours vary over public holidays).

dayInfo.title: Journey to Tehuantepec via Teotitlan del Valle and the Mitla ruins
dayInfo.description: : We have a long journey ahead of us today as we begin to head towards San Cristobal. The drive will lead us up through the winding roads of the Sierra Madre Mountain range and we'll make several stops along the way. Our first port of call is a 2,000-year-old swamp cypress tree in Santa Maria del Tule, close to Oaxaca. The tree has a circumference of 54 metres and has the shortest trunk of any in the world. Next, we'll head to the small town of Teotitlan del Valle, a region where it's more common to hear the Zapotec language than Spanish. Here, weaving has been a local technique since ancient times, and we'll see how the craftsmen make fine works of art. We'll continue to the ancient Mixtec site of Mitla, where we'll have an explanation of the ruins. Finally, we'll journey on to Tehuantepec, a convenient stopping point on our journey to San Cristobal. Note, our drive time today is ten hours, including stops.

dayInfo.title: Sumidero Canyon boat trip and journey to San Cristobal
dayInfo.description: : Leaving early this morning, we'll have a five-hour drive to Cahuare, the starting point for our visit to the spectacular Sumidero Canyon. The canyon is a unique rift measuring 41 kilometres long and up to 1000 metres deep, cut by the Rio Grijalva. This is the spot where, in the 16th century, 1000 Chiapa indigenous people committed suicide rather than submit to Spanish rule. We'll take a trip on a speed boat to fully appreciate the towering gorge, before driving for two hours up a scenic mountain road to San Cristóbal de las Casas. At 2,210 metres above sea level, it can get cold at night, a sharp contrast to the heat of Tehuantepec.

dayInfo.title: Explore indigenous villages of San Juan Chamula and Zinacantan
dayInfo.description: : San Cristobal has a unique atmosphere, located high in the scenic Chiapas Mountain range. The indigenous groups from the surrounding hills fill the town and marketplace with their colourful dress including the distinctive Tzotzil community who still retain much of their Mayan customs and language. Today, we'll be visiting San Juan Chamula and Zinacantan, indigenous villages close to San Cristobal that practise an interesting blend of Catholicism and traditional Maya beliefs. This area is famous for its bright textiles and weavings in intricate designs. You might like to pick up souvenirs here during our free time this afternoon. Much like Oaxaca, San Cristobal is a charming town to explore on foot and also has its fair share of museums. The Na Bolom, House of the Jaguar, is dedicated to the preservation of the Lacandón tribe and displays many of their artefacts, while the Textiles Centre is a superb showcase of the weaving traditions found both in Chiapas as well as the rest of Mexico and Central America. There are also museums dedicated to amber and jade, that not only display historical pieces but also give an understanding of the importance of these materials to the ancient civilisations.

dayInfo.title: Travel to Palenque
dayInfo.description: : Leaving the highlands behind us, today we have a long driving day ahead of us (approximately eight hours, plus stops). The road is slow and winding, but there are scenic views as we descend to the jungles of Palenque. We'll be driving via the town of Villahermosa, where we'll stop for lunch. Along the way there may be the option to stop in the small town of Chontalpa to try the famous piña miel before we continue to our hotel.

dayInfo.title: Explore the Maya site of Palenque
dayInfo.description: : Today's guided visit to the ruins of Palenque is one of the highlights of our tour of Mexico. Palenque is both a fascinating and important site and we'll explore it in depth with a guide. Once the choking forest was cleared, the ruins revealed the tomb of the high priest Pakal, his body adorned with a marvellous jade death mask - one of the most prized relics of the Maya culture, discovered only in 1952. The entire site, shrouded by the steamy rainforest, has an aura of deep mystery.

dayInfo.title: Cross the border into Guatemala and continue on to Flores.
dayInfo.description: : We'll leave Palenque early in the morning and travel for around 3 hours to the El Ceibo Border. After crossing into Guatemala, we'll continue for another 3 hours to the picturesque town of Flores. Located on the shores of Lake Peten Itza, Flores is a very laid-back city with a rich history. It is one of the oldest continuously inhabited settlements in the Americas and was the last Maya city to fall to the Spanish. Today will be a long travel day, and we expect to arrive in Flores in the mid-afternoon.

dayInfo.title: Day trip to Yaxha ruins. Optional boat trip on Lake Peten Itza
dayInfo.description: : After breakfast, we'll leave Flores and drive for two hours to Yaxha, where we'll enjoy a guided tour of the magnificent ruins. This ancient city is located on the shores of two lakes, Yaxha and Sacnab, within the UNESCO-listed Yaxha-Nakum-Naranjo biosphere reserve. This area is rich in rainforests and wetlands, teeming with wildlife. The ruins span several square kilometers and include 500 structures uncovered so far. The city's name, meaning 'green-blue water,' was given thanks to its picturesque lakeside location. We'll spend around two hours exploring the site before stopping for lunch (not included) and returning to Flores. Back in Flores, there will be an opportunity for an optional boat trip on Lake Peten Itza.

dayInfo.title: Explore Tikal, Guatemala
dayInfo.description: : Today we'll visit Tikal, the great Maya metropolis set amid the rainforest, which can justly be compared with the celebrated ancient cities of Egypt and Greece. Initially settled in about 600 BC, Tikal was abandoned by its rulers around 890 AD and totally deserted a hundred years later. The city covered an area of 16 square kilometres. Re-discovered in 1848, only a few of its great temples and pyramids have been excavated. The site is extensive, so we include a guided tour in the morning followed by free time to let you explore. We can appreciate the prolific birdlife in the surrounding rainforest and take in amazing views of the forest canopy from the tops of the pyramids. At 3.30pm, we'll drive back to Flores.

dayInfo.title: Travel to San Ignacio, Belize
dayInfo.description: : Today we'll say goodbye to Guatemala and drive over the border to San Ignacio in Belize. En route, we'll visit the little-known site of Xunantunich, with its fantastic array of pyramids and temples. Then, we'll make our way to our hotel, where the rest of the afternoon is free. If you still have room for one more Mayan sites, the ruins of Cahal Pech are well worth a visit, high up on a hill near the centre of San Ignacio town. Alternatively, you could walk into the town and check out the lively local market (note, the market doesn't run on Sundays).

dayInfo.title: Drive to Belize City Airport where tour ends
dayInfo.description: : Today, we'll drive to Belize City and catch our first glimpse of the Caribbean. In the city, we'll board our water taxi for the one-hour journey to the tropical island of Caye Caulker. Once a pirate lair, this tiny but beautiful island lies 34 kilometres/21 miles northeast of Belize City and about 1.6 kilometres/1 mile inside the greatest barrier reef in the Western Hemisphere. Please note that the seven days in Caye Caulker and the Yucatan are designed as an extension to our Contrasts of Mexico tour. Some of your fellow group members may leave the tour today in Belize City. Whilst the extension has been designed to complement the trip, it's worth noting that it might not be a group experience and you may not be travelling with other customers. Our tour leader from the Contrasts of Mexico tour will accompany you throughout the extension.

dayInfo.title: Relax on Caye Caulker; optional snorkelling trip
dayInfo.description: : The island of Caye Caulker remains uncrowded and authentic - the local fishermen catch lobster, conch, fish and crab to supply domestic and foreign markets. It's a popular place with backpackers, so there's a good number of reasonably priced restaurants. Today, there'll be time to relax or enjoy a number of optional trips. You might like to take a snorkelling trip out to the nearby Hol Chan Marine Reserve and Shark and Ray Alley, or take a full-day trip out to Goff's Caye to observe manatee in their natural mangrove habitat. Scuba diving is also available.

dayInfo.title: Boat back to the mainland then drive to Bacalar
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll leave Caye Caulker by boat, sailing back to the mainland and driving north to the Belizean border before crossing into Mexico at the border crossing 'Subteniente López'. We'll then continue by vehicle to the small town of Bacalar, situated on the banks of the beautiful Lake Bacalar in the Riviera Maya. The lake is frequently named 'the Seven Coloured Lagoon' for its many different shades of blue and has strikingly clear waters thanks to the white limestone bottom. This afternoon is free for you to explore.

dayInfo.title: Visit Tulum before driving to Valladolid
dayInfo.description: : We'll head northeast from Bacalar this morning, towards the ruins of Tulum - situated on a clifftop perch overlooking the turquoise water and golden sands below. The ruins date back to the late period of Mayan civilisation. During this time, there was a developing enmity between Mayan provinces, so the city was guarded by thick ramparts and a watch tower. After visiting the site, we'll continue on to the colonial city of Valladolid, arriving in the late afternoon. We'll have free time to enjoy the picturesque and colourful town centre. Valladolid even has its own cenote just a few blocks away from the main Zocalo, which is a great option for a late afternoon swim.

dayInfo.title: Explore Chichen Itza; travel to Merida
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll visit the ruins of Chichen Itza. Founded in AD432, re-founded in 987 and conquered by the Toltecs in the 10th century, the culture of the Maya and the Toltec gradually fused. The pyramids, palaces, temples and ballcourt (where death was the penalty for defeat) are adorned with astonishing sculptures. Under the pressure of the civil war, the great monuments deteriorated, and the Maya civilisation collapsed, but undeniably Chichen Itza remains one of the most outstanding sites in the Americas - its main pyramid was denoted as the Seventh New Wonder of the World in 2007. After our visit to this extensive site, we'll continue to the beautiful city of Merida. En route we will make a well needed stop at Cenote Yokdzonot for a refreshing dip!

dayInfo.title: Visit the ancient Maya city of Uxmal
dayInfo.description: : We'll have our final site visit this morning; to those in the know, Uxmal is one of the Yucatan's most underrated ancient cities. Encircled by hills, Uxmal is expansive in its design with majestic palaces and pyramids, and long geometrical friezes that rank among the most splendid examples of ancient American Art. The incredible Pyramid of the Magician and the beautiful Governor's Palace are two of the finest examples of Mayan art found in Meso America. Later in the day, we'll return to Merida, where we'll have time to wander the narrow streets, watching the horse-drawn carriages rattle past. Alternatively, there's an option to visit Celestun, the pink flamingo sanctuary.

dayInfo.title: Trip ends in Merida
dayInfo.description: : Our trip ends this morning at our hotel in Merida. There are no activities planned today, so you're free to depart from Merida at any time. If your flight is departing later in the day, luggage storage facilities are available at our hotel. If you'd like an airport transfer today, you'll need to depart from Manuel Crescencio Rejon International Airport (MID) which is approximately a 20-minute drive from the hotel.

tourName: Mexico City & Puebla holiday, tailor made
generalInfo:
Welcome to Mexico, a land of vibrant traditions, breathtaking landscapes, and deep-rooted history. From ancient civilizations to colonial charm and modern creativity, this country offers a rich mosaic of experiences waiting to be discovered.

Whether you're here to explore archaeological wonders, savor world-renowned cuisine, or connect with the warmth of its people, Mexico invites you to slow down, open your senses, and embrace every moment.

We’re delighted to accompany you on this journey. Let the colors, flavors, and stories of Mexico inspire you, this is just the beginning.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to Mexico City, the capital and largest city in Mexico, recognized for its rich history and culture that combines its pre-Hispanic, colonial and present times to offer travelers an endless number of places to visit and a varied gastronomy. Upon arrival, you will be transferred to your hotel, Casa DECU, located in one of the city’s most charming neighborhoods. Settle in and get ready to begin your journey through this vibrant metropolis. Included : Private simple transfer AICM - Hotel in CDMX - 2 bags 25 kg (Private Service) / 5 Nights at Mexico City: Casa Decu Executive Room - 1 dbl bed Continental breakfast

Your private transportation will pick you up to take you to the Historic Center of Mexico City, declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. At the meeting point your local English-speaking guide will be waiting for you to start a walking tour of approximately 4 hours through the streets of the Aztec capital. During this experience you will learn about the history and gastronomy of Mexico while visiting the most emblematic places of the historic center such as the Metropolitan Cathedral, the ruins of the ancient Aztec city, the Palace of Fine Arts and the Postal Palace. You will also make a few stops at local food stalls and restaurants that only your guide knows and taste traditional Mexican food including tacos and a dessert. You will understand why Mexican gastronomy is considered Intangible Cultural Heritage of the Community. At the end of the experience your transportation will take you back to your accommodation. Included : Tortilla crawl: Life beyond tacos experience - 6h - ENG (Private Service) Transport, guide, tasting, dessert - 7:30am, 2pm

Today, you will visit Xochimilco on a 3-hour tour to learn about the pre-Hispanic agricultural system that still operates today: the Chinampas. With your local guide, who speaks Spanish, you will head to the Xochimilco docks, which means Place of Flowers. This is a system of canals divided by small artificial islands called chinampas, which was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1987. You will enjoy a two-hour ride (one hour each way) on a conventional trajinera. During the journey, your guide will tell you about the history of the canals, the endemic species, and the challenges involved in maintaining these canals today. You will arrive at a chinampa, covering just over 3 hectares, nestled in the Protected Natural Area Ejidos of Xochimilco and San Gregorio Atlapulco. There, you will receive a theoretical and practical explanation of the steps followed to produce all kinds of vegetables. Later on, you will tour the planting area, concluding with an explanation of the biofilter, which also serves as a refuge for the region's endemic species, the Axolotl. Upon completing the explanation, you will return to the dock and then to your hotel. included : Chinampa Olintlalli trans service, Coyo & C. Azul - 5h - ENG (Private Service) Roundtrip transport, translation service, trajinera, entrance Demonstrative Chinampa - 2h - SPA (Private Service) Conventional trajinera, guide - 9am to 3pm
Free day

Today, your day will begin at 9:00 AM with your arrival in the community of Zotictla, a village nestled in the heart of nature. You will start with the discovery of La Azucena waterfall, a spectacular natural site where crystal-clear water winds its way through lush vegetation. Take this moment to soak in the tranquility of the surroundings and admire the beauty of this preserved ecosystem. After this immersion in nature, you will hit the road at 1:00 PM toward the community of Santa Ana Tzacuala, where you will be welcomed by local residents for a traditional lunch at 2:00 PM. This meal will allow you to taste typical regional dishes, prepared with local ingredients and recipes passed down from generation to generation. At 3:00 PM, you will attend a demonstration of backstrap loom weaving and traditional embroidery—an ancestral art that is an integral part of the community’s cultural identity. Local artisans will explain the techniques used, the symbolic motifs, and the importance of textiles in indigenous culture. This day will be a full immersion in nature, traditions, and artisanal know-how, offering an authentic glimpse into the lifestyle and cultural richness of these Mexican communities. included : Forest Bath, Traditional Cooking & Weaving Stories-10h- ENG (Private Service) Transport, translator service, food, materials - 7am to 8am

Today your English-speaking local guide will pick you up from your hotel and head out of Mexico City to the valley of Teotihuacan to begin your approximately 8-hour experience. Here, your guide will tell you about the meaning of the City of the Gods, while you walk along the Calzada de los Muertos, telling you all the mysteries of this ancient civilisation, where you will find buildings such as the Pyramid of the Sun and Pyramid of the Moon. Afterwards, you will board your transport that will take you on a tour of the Route of the Murals, an ancient natural observatory and the breathtaking views of the City of the Gods. You’ll close your day with a visit to the home of a family of artisans, where you’ll learn more about the obsidian process and how it is transformed into handicrafts. You will also have a tasting of pulque and products derived from xoconostle, a cactus fruit very representative of the area. At the end of the designated time, you will enjoy a local lunch and your transportation will take you to Cholula, Puebla, where your tour will end. You will be staying at Hotel Casa Azulai. included : Teotihuacán Walking Tour - 9h - ENG (Private Service) Transport DO Puebla/Cholula, guide, entrance, bike, food - 8am / 4 Nights at Puebla: Casa Azulai Puebla Hotel Boutique Standard king room - 1 king bed American breakfast

You will meet your local English speaking guide to start a 4 hour walk through some of the oldest neighborhoods of colonial Puebla, you will head to the market to enjoy its colors, sounds, aromas and of course: its flavors! Then you will meet with a chef to prepare the delicious mole, a unique dish with a variety of ingredients such as chocolate, almonds, sesame seeds, a variety of dried chilies, among others. Of course, the chef will share his traditional cooking secrets with you.
